The movie just reiterated my initial suspicions and concerns about the agenda of the Bush Administration. Concerns that had been shaken by ignorant neo-conservative relatives, peers, and media talking heads. But things are much better now, Bush now has the lowest approval rating since his term began. Kerry isn't exactly the messiah, but he is the lesser of the two evils. Politics aside, the movie re-energized my will to do something about the state of things around here. In Farenheit, there was footage of an Iraqi woman mourning her relatives, crushed under their leveled home in a time of American bombing. She was praying to Allah and claiming that ONLY HE could help her and Iraq. I sat there and realized..."No, we can help. WE can do something about this. OUR vote, OUR words, OUR actions and the lack thereof were, and continue to be responsible in the death and maiming of hundreds daily. AS AMERICANS, not only do we have the power to be mindful of the world community and how each and every one of our actions create repercussions that are felt globally, but we have the RESPONSIBILITY to care and do something." None of our actions are isolated, none of our decisions are an island of ignorant bliss. Here's something I wrote a few months ago. I think it has something to do with what I have been talking about. I read it at the Bard Contest and felt it impacted some people so I'm going to put it up here. urlLink Siddhartha by Hermann Hesse: A searchable online version at The Literature Network Read Siddhartha by Hermann Hesse, it's one of the most important books I've ever read. Here's an excerpt- "Did you," so he asked him at one time, "did you too learn that secret from the river: that there is no time?" Vasudeva's face was filled with a bright smile. "Yes, Siddhartha," he spoke. "It is this what you mean, isn't it: that the river is everywhere at once, at the source and at the mouth, at the waterfall, at the ferry, at the rapids, in the sea, in the mountains, everywhere at once, and that there is only the present time for it, not the shadow of the past, not the shadow of the future?" "This it is," said Siddhartha. "And when I had learned it, I looked at my life, and it was also a river, and the boy Siddhartha was only separated from the man Siddhartha and from the old man Siddhartha by a shadow, not by something real. Also, Siddhartha's previous births were no past, and his death and his return to Brahma was no future. Nothing was, nothing will be; everything is, everything has existence and is present." Siddhartha spoke with ecstasy; deeply, this enlightenment had delighted him. Oh, was not all suffering time, were not all forms of tormenting oneself and being afraid time, was not everything hard, everything hostile in the world gone and overcome as soon as one had overcome time, as soon as time would have been put out of existence by one's thoughts?

urlLink Fundamentals of Buddhism: A Modern Perspective There is no god. I am an atheist, but still consider myself a deeply spiritual person. But the concept of some high-holy authoritative patriarch only raises more questions than it answers. If there was a god, under what circumstances did it come into being? Does this god have a god? Does it question its own existence, just as we do? Inversely, are we the gods of some unfortunate subordinate beings? Theism only winds itself into a tangle of endless and circuitous philosophical quandaries; that is, if you take the time to question it. Religion, whilst having good intentions, is just overgrowth that burdens and distracts the mind. It hides behind a benevolent facade while serving only as a self-indulgent opiate that is based purely on the selfish desire to improve unsatisfactory conditions. Mindless, sheep mentality religion is the kudzu of human consciousness. We must weed our minds and clear our consciousnesses. As Zen Buddhism suggests, everything is illusory, empty, and non-existent. There is something beyond all of our human manifestations, but there is nothing elevated above our everyday experiences, be they mundane or extraordinary. Those false manifestations borne of our conditioned, fragile, and insecure minds (Life & Death, Suffering & Fulfillment, and all of the other dualities we create) are just the residue of our expectations that life is something it is not. The common belief is that this life is not , and only serves as some obligatory requirement to enter heaven or the afterlife. This is life, now , not later. Wake up and savor what is and stop desiring and speculating what is not . "As if you could kill time without harming eternity itself"- Thoreau Time did not start with original sin and it will not cease upon your crossing over the threshold of the Pearly Gates. I don't know why we are here. I don't know what came before or after this life. Nobody knows these things. We know what is in the mind, and that is the extent of our knowledge. Here is a statement based on a buddhist parable that I think applies perfectly to my opinion of life and religion: "The man wounded by an arrow wishes to know who shoots the arrow, from which direction it comes, whether the arrow head is made of bone or iron, whether the shaft is of this kind of wood or another before he will have the arrow removed. This man is likened to those who would like to know about the origin of the Universe, whether the world is eternal or not, finite or not before they will undertake to practise a religion. Just as the man in the parable will die before he has all the answers he wants regarding the origin and nature of the arrow, such people will die before they will ever have the answers to all their irrelevant questions"
